caption_text: EXPERIMENTAL The pyrolysis experiments were conducted in a tu- bular reactor placed vertically and a schematic dia- gram of the experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1. The quartz reactor (i.d.: 22 mm; length = 680 mm) was heated in two electric furnaces. The upper furnace (length: 210 mm; maximum temperature: 1200 K) served as the preheater, whereas the lower furnace (length: 250 mm; maximum temperature: 1700K) was 253 254 M.

caption_text: The average diameter of the fibers was 1.5-2.5 fun and a typical SEM photograph of the as-grown VGCF is shown in Fig. 6. Variations in the duration of length- ening or temperature had no noticeable effect on the fiber morphology. To study the effect of thickening on the average fi- ber length, some experiments were done without thick- ening and the results, shown in Table 1, confirm that there was no significant change in the average fiber length due to thickening.

caption_text: To study the effect of thickening on the average fi- ber length, some experiments were done without thick- ening and the results, shown in Table 1, confirm that there was no significant change in the average fiber length due to thickening. The average fiber diameter without thickening was 1-1.2 ^m as compared to 1.5- 2.5 /un with thickening at 1373 K for 20 minutes.

caption_text: The rate of fiber lengthening dur- ing the initial linear growth period was calculated and is shown in Table 2. At the lower temperatures stud- ied (1283 and 1303 K), the rate of growth was nearly the same at the two concentrations, whereas at 1333 and 1353 K, the rate of lengthening increased with an increase in concentration.
raw_window: The rate of fiber lengthening dur- ing the initial linear growth period was calculated and is shown in Table 2.

At the lower temperatures stud- ied (1283 and 1303 K), the rate of growth was nearly the same at the two concentrations, whereas at 1333 and 1353 K, the rate of lengthening increased with an increase in concentration.
Very meager published in- formation is available on the effect of hydrocarbon concentration on average fiber length.

caption_text: The calculated parameter values are shown in Table 3, whereas the /calculated using the model are shown in Figs. 2 and 3.
raw_window: The calculated parameter values are shown in Table 3, whereas the /calculated using the model are shown in Figs. 2 and 3.
As can be seen from Figs. 2 and 3, the model can satisfactorily correlate the experimental data for the range of conditions investigated.

Accord- ing to the model, kp is a rate constant and if the con- centration of the fiber-forming species, M, also increases with temperature, then kp[M] would be ex- pected to increase with temperature.

caption_text: As shown in Table 3, for both the benzene concentrations studied, kp[M] shows an increasing trend with temperature.

caption_text: For the calculated parameter values (Table 3), M increased by a factor of 1.4-2 when the benzene concentration was increased by a factor of 1.4.
raw_window: For the calculated parameter values (Table 3), M increased by a factor of 1.4-2 when the benzene concentration was increased by a factor of 1.4.
The parameter a represents the probability that a filament will grow rather than terminate and, in gen- eral, a increases with an increase in temperature and a decrease in benzene concentration.
The lower val- ues of a at higher CBo implies that the concentration of the poisoning species, H, is higher, as expected.
